awd_titl_txt: Controlling exciton dynamics at interfaces using moiré potentials
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Two-dimensional (2D) layered crystals, such as transition metal dichalcogenides, have received much attention recently. Notably, their properties can be tailored by stacking different crystals together without the requirement of lattice matching found in traditional inorganic semiconductors. One promising way to control material properties is to vary the relative orientation and the lattice size of the two atomically thin crystals to create a nanoscale moiré pattern. This project will combine 2D-layered crystals with molecular crystals to produce a wide range of moiré patterns. The research team will then investigate the dependence of optical and electronic properties on the different types of moiré patterns. The fundamental knowledge gained by this project allows researchers to create tailor-made interfaces useful in devices such as solar cells, LEDs, and photodetectors, as well as quantum emitters. The project will train undergraduate and graduate students on cutting-edge research capabilities in nanoscale material design, fabrication, and characterization in a collaborative environment. There will be a particular emphasis on recruiting students from underrepresented groups. Outreach activities to the public include a summer camp for K-12 students, outreach seminars, and science outreach websites.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

A wide range of moiré patterns can be created by interfacing 2D transition metal dichalcogenide crystals with organic molecular crystals through weak van der Waals forces. The moiré pattern produces a nanoscale-periodic potential, which in turn provides a unique way to control the electron dynamics at the interface. The research team combines theoretical and experimental efforts to understand how the moiré potential affects the properties of the interlayer exciton (IX) formed at the interface. The goal is to search for interfaces with two distinct classes of moiré potential that favor either photo-to-electrical conversion or light emission, and to demonstrate the moiré potential as an effective way to control the competition between the free carrier generation and the radiative recombination of the IX. A combination of time-resolved and/or angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, and spatiotemporal optical pump-probe spectroscopy are used to probe the IX dynamics and the band structure at the interface. The experimentally measured IX dynamics are correlated with band alignments, interface interactions, and the moiré potential determined by theoretical methods based on density functional theory, including meta-GGAs for rapid screening and hybrid functionals for more accurate calculations. van der Waals interactions are explicitly included. Wannier functions are used to simulate moiré potentials.

por.por_cntn:
This project combined two-dimensional (2D)-layered crystals, such as transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD), with organic molecules to produce a wide range of semiconductor 2D/2D and molecule/2D heterostructures. Our works identified periodic nanoscale potentials at the interface that can be tailored to control optical and electronic properties on the heterostructure.

Intellectual Merit: Time-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy and time-resolved optical spectroscopy were used to measure the interfacial electronic potential, and exciton dynamics of a number of bilayer and trilayer heterostructures. The interpretation of the experimental data was aided by the electronic structure determined by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. We discovered that nanoscale periodic potentials, which resemble those of the moire potential found in TMD/TMD heterostructures, can be produced at the molecules/2D interface through two different mechanisms. First, the lattice of a 2D molecular crystal can be structurally distorted when it is interfaced with a monolayer TMD crystal. This lattice distortion produces spatial modulation in the electronic potential of the molecular layer. Second, the near field from an array of polar molecules can also produce a periodic in-plane potential in the TMD crystal. By using these two strategies, we demonstrated that the periodic potential can produce a periodic array of traps for interlayer exciton (IX) with a very small periodicity (around 2 nanometers).  This small periodicity can increase the IX trap density by an order of magnitude compared to that generated by the moire pattern of TMD/TMD heterostructures. A high IX density favors the formation of correlated phases such as Bose-Einstein condensates. Moreover, we envision that the symmetry, period and magnitude of the potential can be tuned by the shape, size, and dipole/quadrupole moment of the organic molecule. Hence, molecule/2D heterostructures can be a potential platform for hosting various novel electronic phases. Our work resulted in 9 peer-reviewed scientific publications.

Broader Impacts: Van der Waals heterostructures studied in the project have been used in many contemporary optoelectronic applications (e.g. valleytronics, and single-photon emitters) as well as traditional applications (e.g. photovoltaics, photo-catalysts, chemical sensors, tunable molecular transistors, and lasers). These different applications impose different requirements on IX's properties. Our work identified material design rules that can be used to control these properties. The project provided opportunities to a group of 11 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students from three different research groups to work together on collaborative research. Many of these students are from underrepresented groups in physics which includes 5 women, 2 African American/Blacks, 2 Hispanic and 1 Native American. The team organized a summer outreach event called Nano Science Day for local high school students. In this event, students learnt about how physicists design new materials for future electronic and energy applications and acquired hand-on experiences in fabricating 2D heterostructures and dye-sensitized solar cells. The Jayhawk Undergraduate Summer Training (JUST) program was organized each summer, which provided educational and professional development activities to around 10 undergraduate students per year.
